byline.contributor: Azam Ahmed reported from Nochixtlán, and Kirk Semple from Mexico City.
byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE

abstract: Mexican Pres Enrique Pena Nieto's efforts to overhaul national's bureaucratic and wasteful education system prompt violent protests in Oaxaca and several other southern states, leaving thousands of students without school for months; protesters, whose movement has gained traction after government forces kill at least nine demonstrators in Nochixtlan, Mex, say they most oppose rigorous standards for teachers.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of students in Oaxaca State have been without school for months, but after government forces clashed with demonstrators last week, a teachers’ movement appears to have gained steam.

headline.main: Clashes Draw Support for Teachers’ Protest in Mexico
headline.print_headline: Clashes Draw Support for Teachers’ Protest in Mexico

snippet: Thousands of students in Oaxaca State have been without school for months, but after government forces clashed with demonstrators last week, a teachers’ movement appears to have gained steam.
